title: German submarine U-2515
text:
German submarine "U-2515" was a <a href="Type%20XXI%20submarine">Type XXI</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> (one of the ""<a href="Elektroboot">Elektroboot</a>e"") of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>", built for service in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. She was ordered on 6 November 1943, and was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 28 July 1944 at the <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a> yard at <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, as yard number 2515. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 22 September 1944, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Gerhard Linder, on 19 October 1944.
Design.
Like all <a href="Type%20XXI%20submarine">Type XXI</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a>s, "U-2515" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of (<a href="o/a">o/a</a>), a beam of , and a draught of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="MAN%20SE">MAN SE</a> supercharged six-cylinder M6V40/46KBB diesel engines each providing , two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> GU365/30 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting</a> electric motors each providing , and two Siemens-Schuckert <a href="Silent%20running%20%28submarine%29">silent running</a> GV232/28 electric motors each providing .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a submerged speed of . When running on silent motors the boat could operate at a speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate at for ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-2515" was fitted with six <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s in the bow and four <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20warfare">anti-aircraft guns</a>. She could carry twenty-three <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es or seventeen torpedoes and twelve <a href="Naval%20mine">mines</a>. The <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> was five officers and fifty-two men.
Fate.
"U-2515" was damaged in December 1944, by a <a href="naval%20mine">naval mine</a>, in the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. She was sunk by bombs in Dock 111 in Hamburg on 17 January 1945, while damaged sections from the mine were being replaced. The wreck was later raised and broken up.
